newsitem.title: MALAWI: Malawi banks cut lending rates as inflation falls.
newsitem.headline: Malawi banks cut lending rates as inflation falls.

text.p: Malawi commercial banks have cut their lending rates by an average eight percentage points to 29 percent from 37 percent as a result of lower inflation which is expected to fall to single digits by year-end.
The banks also lowered their deposit rates by 10 percentage points to 13 percent.
Reserve Bank Governor Matthews Chikaonda said on Tuesday banks had dropped their lending rates ahead of an anticipated fall in inflation to eight percent in December.
"For the first nine months of the year, the inflation rate has been almost zero. Inflation is coming down (and) as inflation comes down, so do interest rates," Chikaonda told Reuters in an interview.
Monthly inflation was running at 21.5 percent year-on-year in September -- the latest data available -- compared with August's 30.5 per cent.
He said that the country's economy had been turned around, the Kwacha currency had stabilised at 15 kwacha to the dollar and the inflation continued to slump.
"Interest rates in Malawi are liberalised. The commercial banks have to make a business decision," Chikaonda added.
Fred Kanjo, head of economic services at Commercial Bank of Malawi, said the banks had cut their deposit rates in order not to attract too many depositors.
"If we keep our deposit rates high, people will come to us. We don't want to be flooded with too many depositors," Kanjo said.
The cuts in interest rates are effective November 1.
The Reserve Bank cut its lending rates by 10 percentage points to 35 percent in September following a five percentage point cut in June.
